title: Why are Chinese pyramids twice the size of the Egyptian pyramids? What kind of technology was used to increase the size? - Quora

response.answer_text: We’ll start with the second part (the first part’s answer will make sense with it): The mysterious and blatantly futuristic technology of piling dirt.  Working on Qin’s projects, colorized. OK, these ladies are actually Hmong building a home; the actual tomb builders were not so lucky… You can actually build (in theory) any pile at any size: all you have to do is make sure that the pile’s slope is less than that of the angle of repose. However, in practice the pile’s height is limited by the availability of resources: you need a ridiculous quantity of dirt to make even a middling mound.  Qin’s monument. Lot’s of run, very little rise: evidently this is a reflection of emperor Qin’s prowess and power. Personally, I’m skeptical that this was what he was going for, since unlike Khufu’s pyramid, this wasn’t exactly a labor of love by volunteers competitively working for their ruler. The Chinese sort of made it harder on themselves, by ramming the earth all down: it’s way stronger than unconsolidated dirt, but it also needs more dirt. At some point they had to just start using unconsolidated dirt, for maximum volume. It’s why, for example, Qin’s pyramid (see above) has so much volume (and width), but very little height, relative to Khufu’s Pyramid. Originally, it would have only been half the height of the great Pyramid, at around 70–80 m (now, at around 45 m, it’s more like a third); the base is ~350 x 350. It was a truncated pyramid, with the top originally ~50x50. The dimensions give a volume of ~3.7 million cubic meters.  Qin’s tomb, as it would have originally looked. This is indeed bigger in volume than the Khufu’s pyramid, but I think you’d be surprised at how anticlimactically so it is: the pyramid was originally at ~2.6 million. That makes Qin’s tomb 42% bigger than the pyramid by volume, but about half its height. That isn’t remotely close to the “twice the size” of the Great Pyramid (that would require Qin’s pyramid to be 100% bigger than Khufu’s pyramid).  The Great Pyramid: Khufu’s bizarre idea of what a horizon looks like, and proof that and that he was everyone’s daddy. And actually the flimsy-ass construction method has allowed simple erosion to reduce the size of Qin’s pyramid so much, that the difference is now even less: ~3.1 to 2.5 million in Qin’s favor (or 24% larger than the great pyramid). The only way I could get it to actually be double the Great pyramid, is if I use the modern top’s dimensions, and the original height. But that would be fucking stupid—but then it takes a stupid person to make these bizarre claims, so…(no, not the person asking: whoever they got it from). And Qin’s tomb is the largest Chinese tomb of its kind: that’s why I focus on it. The overwhelming majority are much smaller affairs, which Khufu’s pyramid often outsizes. EDIT: oh, yes: it all began apparently with early pilots flying over these. People are shit at judging size without references, so tend to err on the big size. So they started taking 300 m tall pyramids. But as mentioned, in practice the tallest was 76 m—around half “Khufu’s horizon”. Some sheenius then took these uncritically, and spread the misunderstanding around. So to sum up: 1-no, Chinese pyramids were not on the whole, twice the size of the pyramids. This is the case even for the largest one. The most you can say is that they were bigger at times (and purely by volume) 2-They piled dirt. Piling dirt is not particularly hard, or advanced technology. (Tom: thanks for the A2A btw!) Most are not. Such pyramid-like burial mounds as the Chinese built from the ground up aren’t that big. Even the tomb of the first emperor is significantly shorter than the larger Egyptian pyramids. That said, there are some very large pyramidal structures in China, but they were constructed on a very different basis. Rather than being built from the ground up, a good number of imperial family tombs were made by starting with a more or less pyramidal or conical natural hill and shaping it, taking away rocks and dirt to make it the desired form. They were made by extreme landscaping to tear things down, rather than by construction building things up.

Claims of their extreme size are unsubstantiated. Western archeologists have largely been barred from the area. That said, most of the so called “Chinese pyramids" are little more than massive squat piles of dirt used as buried mounds. The “technology" was shovels, buckets, and an endless supply of coree' labor. They aren't actually taller than the Great Pyramid at Giza, but have much larger footprints as they were built out if a much less sturdy material, dirt. You should not believe the sensational things you read online.

Technically speaking, “mounds” are not “pyramids”. And the correct terminology should be : why are Chinese “mounds” twice the size of Egyptian “pyramids”? To which the answer is: many Chinese mounds, as well as many Egyptian mounds, are more than twice the size of Egyptian pyramids because mounds require much less knowledge of structural geometry & construction operation management compared to pyramids. Egyptian mounds were built during the period before Memphis became the capital.  ’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’’ And the world's biggest mounds on record are the Cahokia Mounds built by Native Americans.
